com.hannesdorfmann.mosby.mvp.viewstate.lce.data

Class RetainingFragmentLceViewState<D,V extends MvpLceView<D>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hannesdorfmann.mosby.mvp.viewstate.lce.AbsLceViewState<D,V>
      • com.hannesdorfmann.mosby.mvp.viewstate.lce.data.RetainingLceViewState<D,V>
        • com.hannesdorfmann.mosby.mvp.viewstate.lce.data.RetainingFragmentLceViewState<D,V>
  • Type Parameters:
    D - the data / model type
    V - the type of the view
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    LceViewState<D,V>, ViewState<V>
    Deprecated. 
    Use RetainingLceViewState instead.

    @Deprecated
public class RetainingFragmentLceViewState<D,V extends MvpLceView<D>>
extends RetainingLceViewState<D,V>
    This kind of LceViewState can be used with Activities and Fragments that have set setRetainInstance(true); . This allows to store / restore any kind of data along orientation changes. So this ViewState will not be saved into the Bundle of saveInstanceState(). This ViewState will be stored and restored directly by the Activity or Fragment itself.
    Since:
    1.0.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • RetainingFragmentLceViewState

        public RetainingFragmentLceViewState(Fragment f)
        Deprecated. 
        Creates a new instance. Since most of developers forget to call Fragment#setRetainInstance(boolean) you have to pass the fragment and setRetainInstance(true) will be called for that fragment
        Parameters:
        f - The fragment for this view state. Can be null if you really don't want to setRetainInstanceState(true) automatically, but you should really have a good reason for doing so
